Trading Off Privacy, Utility and Efficiency in Federated Learning

Xiaojin Zhang Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong Yan Kang WeBank, China Kai Chen Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong Lixin Fan WeBank, China Qiang Yang† Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong WeBank, China
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) enables participating parties to collaboratively build a global model with boosted utility without disclosing private data information. Appropriate protection mechanisms have to be adopted to fulfill the opposing requirements in preserving privacy and maintaining high model utility. In addition, it is a mandate for a federated learning system to achieve high efficiency in order to enable large-scale model training and deployment. We propose a unified federated learning framework that reconciles horizontal and vertical federated learning. Based on this framework, we formulate and quantify the trade-offs between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction, which leads us to the No-Free-Lunch (NFL) theorem for the federated learning system. NFL indicates that it is unrealistic to expect an FL algorithm to simultaneously provide excellent privacy, utility, and efficiency in certain scenarios. We then analyze the lower bounds for the privacy leakage, utility loss and efficiency reduction for several widely-adopted protection mechanisms including Randomization, Homomorphic Encryption, Secret Sharing and Compression. Our analysis could serve as a guide for selecting protection parameters to meet particular requirements.

$\dagger$$\dagger$footnotetext: Corresponding author

Keywords: federated learning, privacy, utility, efficiency, trade-off,divergence, optimization

1 Introduction

The rapid expansion of large-scale datasets has sparked a demand for distributed learning. With the enforcement of data privacy regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the data owned by one company is not allowed to be disclosed to others. Federated learning (FL) [31, 32, 24, 25, 28] meets this requirement by allowing multiple parties to train a machine learning model collaboratively without sharing private data. In recent years, FL has achieved significant progress in developing privacy-preserving machine learning systems. It has been extended from the conventional horizontal federated learning (HFL) to the vertical federated learning (VFL) scenarios [46, 22, 18]. HFL typically involves a large amount of parties with different samples but share the same feature space. While VFL typically involves a handful of parties that own distinct features of the same set of sample instances. HFL is popular in healthcare and mobile applications [36, 2, 21, 27], while VFL is widely adopted in finance and advertisement [4, 39, 23].

Preserving privacy is of immense practical importance when federating across different parties. Although the private data of each client is not shared with other collaborators, the private information might still be reconstructed by semi-honest parties upon observing the shared model information [15, 51, 47, 26, 14]. The fundamental requirement for maintaining privacy is to keep potential privacy leakage below an acceptable level. This is accomplished by reducing the dependence between shared model information and private data. To protect private data of the participants, many protection mechanisms have been proposed, such as Randomization Mechanism [17, 41, 1], Secret Sharing [38, 5, 6], Homomorphic Encryption (HE) [16, 48], and Compression Mechanism [33]. However, the adoption of these protection mechanisms might result in a certain amount of utility loss and efficiency reduction, as compared with a federated model trained without any protection [11, 23]. As a result, theoretical analysis of the trade-off between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction is critical for guiding FL practitioners to choose better protection parameters or design smarter FL algorithms.

Motivated by this goal, the work [50] proposed a statistical framework to analyze the privacy-utility trade-off in FL on a rigorous theoretical foundation. However, its trade-off analysis did not involve efficiency, which is a crucial factor in designing FL algorithms. Besides, [50] did not consider the VFL setting, which has a broad range of applications in finance and advertisement. These gaps inspire us to investigate the following crucial open problem: is it possible to design a protection mechanism that simultaneously achieves infinitesimal privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction? Our main finding is crystallized in a No-Free-Lunch (NFL) Theorem (Theorem 4.6) that provides a negative answer for this question in certain scenarios under a unified FL framework that reconciles both HFL and VFL settings. For the outline of our work, please refer to Figure 6.

Our contributions are as follows:

  • •

    We propose a unified FL framework (see Section 5) for HFL and VFL. The unified FL framework provides a conceptual view of the relationship between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction through the lens of the protector and the adversary. Our No-Free-Lunch theorem is formulated based on this framework, and thus it applies to both HFL and VFL.

  • •

    We provide a No-Free-Lunch theorem (Theorem 4.6) for federated learning, which quantifies the trade-off between privacy leakage (Def. 3.3), utility loss (Def. 3.4) and efficiency reduction (Def. 3.5). This quantification indicates that the weighted summation of the privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction is greater than a problem-dependent non-zero constant. It characterizes the amount of utility and efficiency that is inevitable to lose in the case that the privacy leakage budget is unduly low.

  • •

    We apply the NFL theorem to analyze trade-offs between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction for widely-adopted protection mechanisms, including Randomization, Homomorphic Encryption, Secret Sharing and Compression. The trade-off is characterized via the lower bounds derived for privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction.

2 Related Work

The related work for attacking mechanisms and protection mechanisms in federated learning and privacy-utility-efficiency trade-off are briefly reviewed in this section.

2.1 Attacking Mechanisms and Protection Mechanisms in Federated Learning

We focus on semi-honest adversaries who faithfully follow the federated learning protocol but may infer the private information of other participants based on the exposed model information.

In HFL, [52, 15, 51, 47] demonstrate that adversaries could exploit gradient information to restore the private image data to pixel-level accuracy, with distinct settings of prior distributions and conditional distributions. A variety of protection mechanisms have been proposed in HFL to prevent private data from being deduced by adversarial participants. The most popular ones are Homomorphic Encryption (HE) [16, 48], Randomization Mechanism [17, 41, 1], Secret Sharing [38, 5, 6] and Compression Mechanism [33]. Another school of FL [20, 19] tries to protect privacy by splitting a neural network into private and public models and sharing only the public one [23, 19].

VFL has two kinds of privacy leakage: feature leakage and label leakage. It is challenging for the adversary to infer the features of other parties because, in production VFL, participating parties typically have black-box knowledge about each other. The literature has proposed mainly two kinds of label inference attacks in VFL: the gradient-based [26] and the model-based [14] attacks.  [26] also demonstrated three noise-based protections that can prevent gradient-based attacks. [53] proposed a data encoding protection mechanism called CoAE that can thwart model-based attacks effectively in some scenarios. Crypto-based protections are widely adopted in federated logistic regression and XGBoost. However, they are seldom applied to VNN that involves complex neural networks for their high communication and computational cost.

2.2 Privacy-Utility-Efficiency Trade-off

In the past decade, there has been wide interest in understanding the privacy-utility trade-off [10, 30, 37, 44, 42, 35, 50]. [10, 30] quantified the privacy-utility trade-off using the solution of the optimization problem. [37] provided a privacy-utility trade-off region for the special case with i.i.d. data sources and known distribution. [35] illustrated that the optimal privacy-utility trade-off could be solved using a standard linear program and provided a closed-form solution for the special case when the data to be released is a binary variable. [44] measured distortion using the expected Hamming distance between the input and output databases and measured privacy leakage using identifiability, differential privacy, and mutual-information privacy separately. [42] provided a trade-off when utility and privacy were evaluated using χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}-based information measures. [43] analyzed the trade-off between the speed of error convergence and the wall-clock time for distributed SGD. [7] analyzed the trade-off between communication, privacy, and accuracy for distributed statistical tasks. The accuracy is measured using statistical mean estimation, frequency estimation, and distribution estimation separately, and the privacy is measured using differential privacy. However, none of these works focus on federated learning and measure utility using model performance.

The work [50] proposed a quantitative trade-off between utility and privacy in horizontal federated learning by exploiting some key properties of the privacy leakage and the triangle inequality of the divergence. [29] evaluated the accuracy-privacy-cost trade-off for federated learning empirically. In this work, we offer a general theoretical analysis of the trade-off between privacy, utility, and efficiency that applies to both HFL and VFL.

3 A Unified Federated Learning Framework

In this section, we first introduce general notations used throughout this work. Then, we propose a unified federated learning framework with a conceptual view of the relationship between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction. Next, we provide formal definitions for key components of this framework, including protection and attacking mechanisms, privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction. We then formulate the goal of the protector as a constrained optimization problem and put forward a critical question with which we are concerned. Our No-Free-Lunch theorem provides an answer for this problem formulated based on this framework, and thus it applies to both HFL and VFL.

3.1 Notations

We adhere to the tradition of using uppercase letters to indicate the random variables, such as D𝐷D, and lowercase letters to denote the specific values they take on. We represent [K]delimited-[]𝐾[K] as {1,2,⋯,K}12⋯𝐾\{1,2,\cdots,K\}. We use lowercase letters such as f𝑓f and p𝑝p to denote probability density functions and uppercase letters such as F𝐹F and P𝑃P to denote distributions.

The probability density function f𝑓f at value d𝑑d is represented by fDk​(d)subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑f_{D_{k}}(d), and the subindex represents the random variable. The conditional density function is denoted by the notation fDk|Wk​(d|w)subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤f_{D_{k}|W_{k}}(d|w). Let p𝑝p and q𝑞q represent the probability densities (or probability masses) of P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q for distributions P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q over ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}. The Jensen-Shannon divergence, which is a smoothed variation of the Kullback-Leibler divergence, is defined as JS(P||Q)=12[KL(P,M)+KL(Q,M)]\text{JS}(P||Q)=\frac{1}{2}\left[\text{KL}\left(P,M\right)+\text{KL}\left(Q,M\right)\right] with M=(P+Q)/2𝑀𝑃𝑄2M=(P+Q)/2. Let TV(P||Q)\text{TV}(P||Q) denote the total variation distance between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q, which is defined as TV(P||Q)=supA⊂ℝn|P(A)−Q(A)|\text{TV}(P||Q)=\sup_{A\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}}|P(A)-Q(A)|. 3.2 The Conceptual View of the Unified Federated Learning Framework

In this section, we propose a unified federated learning framework that unifies HFL and VFL through a conceptual view of the relationship between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction via the lens of the protector and the adversary. We first introduce HFL and VFL and unify their terminologies and notations. Then, we elaborate on this conceptual view.

HFL has two representative aggregation implementations: FedAvg and FedSGD, which are mathematically equivalent. Our framework applies to both aggregations. For illustrative purposes, we use FedAvg to explain the procedure of secure horizontal federated learning:

  1. With the global model state from the server, each client k𝑘k trains its local model using its private data set Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}, and obtains the local model θk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝒪\theta_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}.

  2. In order to prevent the semi-honest adversaries from inferring other clients’ private information Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} according to θk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝒪\theta_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}, each client k𝑘k adopts a protection mechanism M𝑀M to convert model θk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝒪\theta_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} to protected model θk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝒮\theta_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}, and sends θk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝒮\theta_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} to the server.

  3. The server aggregates θk𝒮,k=1,⋯,Kformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝒮𝑘1⋯𝐾\theta_{k}^{\mathcal{S}},k=1,\cdots,K to generate a new global model θagg𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃agg𝒮\theta_{\text{agg}}^{\mathcal{S}}.

  4. Each client k𝑘k downloads the global model θagg𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃agg𝒮\theta_{\text{agg}}^{\mathcal{S}} and uses it to update its local model.

The processes ①-④ iterate until the utility of the aggregated model θagg𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃agg𝒮\theta_{\text{agg}}^{\mathcal{S}} does not improve.

In VFL, without loss of generality, we consider a 2-client scenario where client 1 (has no labels) is the adversary who wants to recover the labels owned by client 2. The overall secure vertical federated learning procedure is illustrated on the right panel of Fig. 1 and summarized as follows:

  1. Client 1 and 2 compute their model outputs u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} based on their local bottom model information using their corresponding local data sets, respectively.

  2. Client 1 sends u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} to client 2.

  3. Client 2 aggregates u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} and then feeds the aggregated result to its top model θ2,t𝒪superscriptsubscript𝜃2𝑡𝒪\theta_{2,t}^{\mathcal{O}} to generate the predicted labels, which further is used to compute loss against the ground truth label y𝑦y.

  4. Client 2 updates its top model θ2,t𝒪superscriptsubscript𝜃2𝑡𝒪\theta_{2,t}^{\mathcal{O}} and continues to compute the derivatives g1subscript𝑔1g_{1} and g2subscript𝑔2g_{2} of the loss L𝐿L w.r.t. u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2}, respectively.

  5. In order to prevent the adversarial client 1 from inferring labels of client 2 based on g1subscript𝑔1g_{1}, client 2 adopts protection mechanism M𝑀M to convert g1subscript𝑔1g_{1} to protected g1𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝒮g_{1}^{\mathcal{S}}, and sends g1𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝒮g_{1}^{\mathcal{S}} to client 1.

  6. Clients 1 and 2 update their local bottom model θ1,b𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃1𝑏𝒮\theta_{1,b}^{\mathcal{S}} and θ2,b𝒪superscriptsubscript𝜃2𝑏𝒪\theta_{2,b}^{\mathcal{O}} based on g1𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝒮g_{1}^{\mathcal{S}} and g2subscript𝑔2g_{2}, respectively.

The processes ①-⑥ iterate until the utility of the joint model θjoint𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃joint𝒮\theta_{\text{joint}}^{\mathcal{S}} does not improve.

For the convenience of our analysis, we unify the terminologies and notations used for HFL and VFL (summarized in Table 2). The final trained model in HFL is typically called aggregated model, while the one in VFL is called joint model. We refer to them as federated model. The private information of HFL typically involves private features, labels, and statistical information; the one we study in this work for VFL is private labels. We refer to them all as private information. In HFL, the information exploited by the attacker to infer the private information of protector k𝑘k is θk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝒮\theta_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} if the attacker is the server, and is θagg𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃agg𝒮\theta_{\text{agg}}^{\mathcal{S}} if the attacker is the client (see Figure 1 left). In VFL, the exploited information is referred to as gk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝒮g_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} (see Figure 1 right). We unify them as Wk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} and Wfed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒮W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}. The utility of the federated model of HFL is usually defined as 1K​∑k=1KUk​(θagg𝒮)1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑈𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃agg𝒮\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}U_{k}(\theta_{\text{agg}}^{\mathcal{S}}), while the one of VFL is U​(θjoint𝒮)𝑈superscriptsubscript𝜃joint𝒮U(\theta_{\text{joint}}^{\mathcal{S}}). We unify them as U​(Wfed𝒮)𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒮U(W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}).

Horizontal and vertical federated learning are the two primary forms of federated learning. While they have distinct training procedures, their privacy-preserving problem can be boiled down to the competition between the adversary and the protector. The former tries to learn as much private information on D𝐷D as possible via privacy attacks. At the same time, the latter applies protection mechanisms to mitigate privacy leakage while maintaining utility loss and efficiency reduction below an acceptable level.

Figure 2 gives our proposed unified federated learning framework that illustrates the relationship between the privacy leakage ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}, utility loss ϵesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒\epsilon_{e} and efficiency reduction ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u} through the lens of the adversary and the protector. Specifically, to protect the privacy of its local data D𝐷D, the protector converts the plain-text message m​s​g𝑚𝑠𝑔msg to protected one m​s​g𝒮𝑚𝑠superscript𝑔𝒮msg^{\mathcal{S}} exposed to the adversary aiming to mitigate the privacy leakage while maintaining the utility loss below an acceptable level. On the other hand, the adversary launches privacy attacks on protected model information W𝒮superscript𝑊𝒮W^{\mathcal{S}} aiming to infer as much information on D𝐷D as possible. Since protection mechanisms may jeopardize model utility and reduce efficiency, the protector needs to control the strength of the applied protection mechanism to strike a balance between private leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction.

The unified FL framework provides a conceptual view of the relationship between ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}, ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u}, and ϵesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒\epsilon_{e} through the lens of the protector and the adversary, regardless of the underlying FL architecture. Thus, it also reconciles other FL architectures, such as peer-to-peer (P2P) FL. In this work, we propose the No-Free-Lunch (NFL) theorem that quantifies the trade-off between ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}, ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u}, and ϵesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒\epsilon_{e} from the perspective of the protector of our unified federated learning framework. Thus, the NFL theorem applies to HFL, VFL, and P2P FL (e.g., Swarm Learning [45]).

3.3 Protection and Privacy Attacking Mechanisms

3.3.1 Protection Mechanisms

The data protector applies certain protection mechanisms to the exposed model information to mitigate privacy leakage. We formally define the protection mechanism as follows:

Definition 3.1 (Protection Mechanism and Protected Distribution).

The protection mechanism M:ℝm→ℝm:𝑀→superscriptℝ𝑚superscriptℝ𝑚M:\mathbb{R}^{m}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{m} maps the original model information Wk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}, which follows a distribution Pk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒪P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}, to its protected (or distorted) counterpart Wk𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝒮𝑘W^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}, which follows a distribution Pk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}. The objective of M𝑀M is to protect private data so that the dependency between Wk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} and Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} is reduced, compared to the dependency between the unprotected information Wk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} and Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}. The distribution Pk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} is referred to as the protected distribution of client k𝑘k.

EXAMPLE: We take the randomization mechanism as an illustrative example and introduce the protected distribution. Assume that Wk𝒪∼Pk𝒪=𝒩​(μ0,Σ0)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒪𝒩subscript𝜇0subscriptΣ0W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}\sim P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}=\mathcal{N}(\mu_{0},\Sigma_{0}), and ϵk∼𝒩​(0,Σϵ)similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘𝒩0subscriptΣitalic-ϵ\epsilon_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\Sigma_{\epsilon}), where Σ0=diag​(σ12,⋯,σn2)subscriptΣ0diagsuperscriptsubscript𝜎12⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\Sigma_{0}=\text{diag}(\sigma_{1}^{2},\cdots,\sigma_{n}^{2}), Σϵ=diag​(σϵ2,⋯,σϵ2)subscriptΣitalic-ϵdiagsuperscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2\Sigma_{\epsilon}=\text{diag}(\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2},\cdots,\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}). Then the protected parameter Wk𝒮=Wk𝒪+ϵk∼𝒩​(μ0,Σ0+Σϵ)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘similar-to𝒩subscript𝜇0subscriptΣ0subscriptΣitalic-ϵW_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}=W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}+\epsilon_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu_{0},\Sigma_{0}+\Sigma_{\epsilon}). That is, the protected distribution Pk𝒮=𝒩​(μ0,Σ0+Σϵ)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮𝒩subscript𝜇0subscriptΣ0subscriptΣitalic-ϵP_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}=\mathcal{N}(\mu_{0},\Sigma_{0}+\Sigma_{\epsilon}). Please refer to Section D for more details.

In this work, we consider widely-adopted protection mechanisms, including Randomization Mechanism, Homomorphic Encryption, Secret Sharing and Compression Mechanism.

3.3.2 Privacy Attacking Mechanisms

The requirement of adopting specific protection mechanisms depends on the adversary’s threat model. We consider the adversary to be semi-honest, he/she faithfully adheres to the federated learning protocol, yet may execute privacy attacks on exposed data to deduce the private information of other participants.

Let Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} denote private features or labels in horizontal federated learning and denote labels in vertical federated learning. Let Wksubscript𝑊𝑘W_{k} represent the model information exposed by client k𝑘k. Let fDk|Wksubscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘f_{D_{k}|W_{k}} represent the probability density function of the posterior distribution FDk|Wksubscript𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘F_{D_{k}|W_{k}}. Next, we introduce the Bayesian Inference Attack that estimates the private information by maximizing the posterior belief fDk|Wksubscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘f_{D_{k}|W_{k}}.

Definition 3.2 (Bayesian Inference Attack).

Given the distorted model information Wk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}, the Bayesian Inference Attack finds data d𝑑d that maximizes the posterior belief:

arg⁡maxd⁡IH​(d|w)=arg⁡maxd⁡[I​(w|d)+H​(d)],subscript𝑑IHconditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑑Iconditional𝑤𝑑H𝑑\displaystyle\arg\max\limits_{d}\text{IH}(d|w)=\arg\max\limits_{d}[\text{I}(w|d)+\text{H}(d)], (1)

where IH​(d|w)=log⁡fDk|Wk𝒮​(d|w)IHconditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮conditional𝑑𝑤\text{IH}(d|w)=\log f_{{D_{k}}|{W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}}(d|w) corresponds to the logarithm of the posterior belief, I​(w|d)=log⁡fWk𝒮|Dk​(w|d)Iconditional𝑤𝑑subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮subscript𝐷𝑘conditional𝑤𝑑\text{I}(w|d)=\log f_{W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}|D_{k}}(w|d) measures the logarithm of the likelihood based on the observed model information w𝑤w, and H​(d)=log⁡fDk​(d)H𝑑subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\text{H}(d)=\log f_{D_{k}}(d) represents the logarithm of the prior belief fDk​(d)subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑f_{{D_{k}}}(d). According to Bayes’ theorem, maximizing the logarithm of posterior fDk|Wk𝒮​(d|w)subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮conditional𝑑𝑤f_{D_{k}|W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}(d|w) on Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} involves maximizing summation of log⁡(fWk𝒮|Dk​(w|d))subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮subscript𝐷𝑘conditional𝑤𝑑\log(f_{W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}|D_{k}}(w|d)) and log⁡(fDk​(d))subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\log(f_{D_{k}}(d)).

Below, we introduce some representative privacy attacks (see Table 3) that fall under the family of the Bayesian Inference Attack.

Privacy Attacks in HFL

The following attacking mechanisms proposed for HFL fit into the Bayesian inference attack framework formulated in Eq. (1). These attacks infer private data d𝑑d through maximizing the similarity between the observed gradient g𝑔g and the estimated gradient ∇wℒ​(d,w)subscript∇𝑤ℒ𝑑𝑤\nabla_{w}\mathcal{L}(d,w) with different prior on d𝑑d (w𝑤w here corresponds to θk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝒮\theta_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} in the left panel of Figure 1).

    Inverting Gradients [15]: H​(d)H𝑑\text{H}(d) is the TV loss of estimated data, denoted as TV​(d)TV𝑑{\text{TV}}(d); I​(w|d)Iconditional𝑤𝑑\text{I}(w|d) corresponds to the cosine similarity between the observed gradient g𝑔g and the estimated gradient ∇wℒ​(d,w)subscript∇𝑤ℒ𝑑𝑤\nabla_{w}\mathcal{L}(d,w).

  • •

    Improved DLG [51]): H​(d)H𝑑\text{H}(d) is the prior with the label information of d𝑑d, denoted as Label​(d)Label𝑑\text{Label}(d); I​(w|d)Iconditional𝑤𝑑\text{I}(w|d) corresponds to the negative ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} distance between the observed gradient g𝑔g and the estimated gradient ∇wℒ​(d,w)subscript∇𝑤ℒ𝑑𝑤\nabla_{w}\mathcal{L}(d,w).

  • •

    GradInversion [47]: H​(d)H𝑑\text{H}(d) is the group consistency of estimated data, denoted as Group​(d)Group𝑑\text{Group}(d); I​(w|d)Iconditional𝑤𝑑\text{I}(w|d) corresponds to the negative ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} distance between the observed gradient g𝑔g and the estimated gradient ∇wℒ​(d,w)subscript∇𝑤ℒ𝑑𝑤\nabla_{w}\mathcal{L}(d,w).

Privacy Attacks in VFL

We focus on label inference attacks because labels may contain sensitive user information, and they are typically valuable assets in real-world VFL applications such as finance, healthcare, and advertisement. More specifically, we consider gradient scoring attack and direct label inference attack, which comply with the Bayesian inference attack framework. Both attacks are mounted by client 1, aiming to infer labels owned by client 2 based on back-propagated gradient w𝑤w (w𝑤w here corresponds to g1𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝒮g_{1}^{\mathcal{S}} in the right panel of Figure 1).

  • •

    Gradient Scoring Attack. I​(w|d)=N​(∑i=1ψ𝟙​{r​(w)∈[li,vi]}⋅𝟙​{d∈Ci})Iconditional𝑤𝑑𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜓⋅1𝑟𝑤subscript𝑙𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖1𝑑subscript𝐶𝑖\text{I}(w|d)=N\left(\sum_{i=1}^{\psi}\mathbbm{1}\{r(w)\in[l_{i},v_{i}]\}\cdot\mathbbm{1}\{d\in C_{i}\}\right), where r:ℝm→[0,1]:𝑟→superscriptℝ𝑚01r:\mathbb{R}^{m}\rightarrow[0,1] denotes a scoring function; d𝑑d represents one data point; lisubscript𝑙𝑖l_{i} and visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} denotes the lower bound and upper bound, respectively; ψ𝜓\psi represents the total number of classes; Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} represents class i𝑖i; N​(⋅)𝑁⋅N(\cdot) computes the logarithm of the normalized input. H​(d)=constantH𝑑constant\text{H}(d)=\text{constant}. The gradient scoring attack typically applies to the binary classification task. The attacker needs to design a scoring function satisfying that r​(w)∈[l1,v1]𝑟𝑤subscript𝑙1subscript𝑣1r(w)\in[l_{1},v_{1}] if the corresponding data of w𝑤w belongs to the negative class, and r​(w)∈[l2,v2]𝑟𝑤subscript𝑙2subscript𝑣2r(w)\in[l_{2},v_{2}] if the corresponding data of w𝑤w belongs to the positive class. A case in point is the Norm-based Scoring Attack (NBS) [26], which observes that ‖w‖2subscriptnorm𝑤2\|w\|_{2} of the positive instances are generally larger than that of the negative ones and formulates the attacking problem as the classification problem.

  • •

    Direct Label Inference Attack (DLI) [14]. DLI is tailored to the VFL scenario where the top model owned by client 2 is an activation function (e.g., softmax) [28], the adversary has access to the gradients of the final activation function, and thus it can infer labels through the signs of back-propagated gradients. In DLI, I(w|d)=N(∑i=1ψ𝟙{wi∈([li,vi]}⋅𝟙{d∈Ci})\text{I}(w|d)=N\left(\sum_{i=1}^{\psi}\mathbbm{1}\{w_{i}\in([l_{i},v_{i}]\}\cdot\mathbbm{1}\{d\in C_{i}\}\right), where li=−∞subscript𝑙𝑖l_{i}=-\infty and vi=0subscript𝑣𝑖0v_{i}=0 if d∈Ci𝑑subscript𝐶𝑖d\in C_{i}; li=0subscript𝑙𝑖0l_{i}=0 and vi=+∞subscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}=+\infty otherwise; H​(d)=constantH𝑑constant\text{H}(d)=\text{constant}. Thus, if wi<0subscript𝑤𝑖0w_{i}<0 its corresponding data point d𝑑d belongs to class Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} and if wi>0subscript𝑤𝑖0w_{i}>0 the data point d𝑑d does not belong to class Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}.

Remark: Attacking mechanisms, such as the model completion attack [14], that use the cumulative information over rounds and is beyond the scope of our article.

3.4 Privacy Leakage, Utility Loss and Efficiency Reduction

In this section, we formally define privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction (depicted in Figure 2).

The privacy leakage (Definition 3.3) measures the variation between the adversary’s prior and posterior beliefs on private information. The adversary obtains the posterior belief by mounting a Bayesian inference attack (Definition 3.2) on the protected model information. Thus, we formally call the privacy leakage the Bayesian privacy leakage. The protected model information may lead to the federated model with lower utility (Definition 3.4) and the federated training with less efficiency (Definition 3.5) in certain scenarios.

Let Fk𝒜subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝒜𝑘F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}, Fk𝒪subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝒪𝑘F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k} and Fkℬsubscriptsuperscript𝐹ℬ𝑘F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k} represent the attacker’s belief distributions about Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} upon observing the protected information, the original information and without observing any information, respectively, and the probability density functions of which are fDk𝒜,fDk𝒪subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝒜subscript𝐷𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝒪subscript𝐷𝑘f^{\mathcal{A}}_{D_{k}},f^{\mathcal{O}}_{D_{k}}, and fDkℬsubscriptsuperscript𝑓ℬsubscript𝐷𝑘f^{\mathcal{B}}_{D_{k}}. Specifically, fDk𝒜​(d)=∫𝒲kfDk|Wk​(d|w)​𝑑Pk𝒮​(w)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝒜subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑subscriptsubscript𝒲𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤differential-dsubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝒮𝑘𝑤f^{\mathcal{A}}_{D_{k}}(d)=\int_{\mathcal{W}_{k}}f_{{D_{k}}|{W_{k}}}(d|w)dP^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}(w), fDk𝒪​(d)=∫𝒲kfDk|Wk​(d|w)​𝑑Pk𝒪​(w)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝒪subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑subscriptsubscript𝒲𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤differential-dsubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝒪𝑘𝑤f^{\mathcal{O}}_{D_{k}}(d)=\int_{\mathcal{W}_{k}}f_{{D_{k}}|{W_{k}}}(d|w)dP^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}(w), and fDkℬ​(d)=fDk​(d)subscriptsuperscript𝑓ℬsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑑subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑f^{\mathcal{B}}_{D_{k}}(d)=f_{D_{k}}(d).

We use JS divergence to measure the privacy leakage instead of KL divergence. The advantage of JS divergence over KL divergence is that it is symmetrical, and its square root satisfies the triangle inequality [12]. This property facilitates the quantification of the trade-offs.

Definition 3.3 (Bayesian Privacy Leakage).

Let ϵp,ksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑘\epsilon_{p,k} represent the privacy leakage of client k𝑘k, which is defined as:

ϵp,k=JS(Fk𝒜||Fkℬ),\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,k}=\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}, (2)

where JS(Fk𝒜||Fkℬ)=12∫𝒟kfDk𝒜(d)logfDk𝒜​(d)fDkℳ​(d)dμ(d)+12∫𝒟kfDkℬ(d)logfDkℬ​(d)fDkℳ​(d)dμ(d){\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})=\frac{1}{2}\int_{\mathcal{D}_{k}}f^{\mathcal{A}}_{D_{k}}(d)\log\frac{f^{\mathcal{A}}_{D_{k}}(d)}{f^{\mathcal{M}}_{D_{k}}(d)}\textbf{d}\mu(d)+\frac{1}{2}\int_{\mathcal{D}_{k}}f^{\mathcal{B}}_{D_{k}}(d)\log\frac{f^{\mathcal{B}}_{D_{k}}(d)}{f^{\mathcal{M}}_{D_{k}}(d)}\textbf{d}\mu(d), Fk𝒜subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝒜𝑘F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k} and Fkℬsubscriptsuperscript𝐹ℬ𝑘F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k} represent the attacker’s belief distribution about Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} upon observing the protected information and without observing any information, respectively, and fDkℳ​(d)=12​(fDk𝒜​(d)+fDkℬ​(d))superscriptsubscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘ℳ𝑑12subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝒜subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑓ℬsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑑f_{D_{k}}^{\mathcal{M}}(d)=\frac{1}{2}(f^{\mathcal{A}}_{D_{k}}(d)+f^{\mathcal{B}}_{D_{k}}(d)).

Furthermore, the Bayesian privacy leakage in FL resulting from releasing the protected model information is defined as:

ϵp=1K​∑k=1Kϵp,k.subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\epsilon_{p,k}.

Remark:
(1) The local model information WksubscriptWkW_{k} represents the model parameters, model gradients and model outputs, all of which may optionally be exchanged or get exposed to semi-honest adversaries.

(2) If the private information Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} is continuous, then

JS(Fk𝒜||Fkℬ)\displaystyle{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k}) =12​[KL​(Fk𝒜,Fkℳ)+KL​(Fkℬ,Fkℳ)]absent12delimited-[]KLsubscriptsuperscript𝐹𝒜𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝐹ℳ𝑘KLsubscriptsuperscript𝐹ℬ𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝐹ℳ𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}\left[\text{KL}\left(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k},F^{\mathcal{M}}_{k}\right)+\text{KL}\left(F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k},F^{\mathcal{M}}_{k}\right)\right]

If the private information Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} is discrete, then

When evaluating the utility loss, we consider the scenario when each protector is assigned a private key (if one exists).

Definition 3.4 (Utility Loss).

The utility loss of client k𝑘k (denoted as ϵu,ksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑘\epsilon_{u,k}) measures the variation in utility of client k𝑘k with the federated model drawn from unprotected distribution Pfed𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒪P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}} and the utility of the federated model drawn from protected distribution Pfed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒮P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}:

ϵu,k=𝔼Wfed𝒪∼Pfed𝒪​[Uk​(Wfed𝒪)]−𝔼Wfed𝒮∼Pfed𝒮​[Uk​(Wfed𝒮)],subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑘subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒪delimited-[]subscript𝑈𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝒪fedsubscript𝔼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒮delimited-[]subscript𝑈𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒮\displaystyle\epsilon_{u,k}=\mathbb{E}_{W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}}\sim P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}}}[U_{k}(W^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}})]-\mathbb{E}_{W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}\sim P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}}[U_{k}(W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}})],

where Uksubscript𝑈𝑘U_{k} represents the utility function of client k𝑘k. Furthermore, the utility loss in FL system is defined as:

ϵu=𝔼Wfed𝒪∼Pfed𝒪​[U​(Wfed𝒪)]−𝔼Wfed𝒮∼Pfed𝒮​[U​(Wfed𝒮)],subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒪delimited-[]𝑈subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝒪fedsubscript𝔼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒮delimited-[]𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒮\displaystyle\epsilon_{u}=\mathbb{E}_{W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}}\sim P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}}}[U(W^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}})]-\mathbb{E}_{W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}\sim P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}}[U(W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}})],

where U𝑈U represents the utility function of the FL system.

Efficiency reduction is another criterion we consider in this work, and defined as follows.

Definition 3.5 (Efficiency Reduction).

Let ϵe,ksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒𝑘\epsilon_{e,k} represent the efficiency reduction of client k𝑘k. The efficiency reduction of client k𝑘k measures the variation in efficiency with the models drawn from the unprotected and protected distributions Pk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒪P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} and Pk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}, which is defined as:

ϵe,k=𝔼Wk𝒮∼Pk𝒮​[C​(Wk𝒮)]−𝔼Wk𝒪∼Pk𝒪​[C​(Wk𝒪)],subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒𝑘subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮delimited-[]𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝒮𝑘subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒪delimited-[]𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝒪𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{e,k}=\mathbb{E}_{W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}\sim P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}[C(W^{\mathcal{S}}_{k})]-\mathbb{E}_{W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}\sim P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}}[C(W^{\mathcal{O}}_{k})],

where C𝐶C denotes a mapping from the model information to the efficiency measured in terms of the communication cost (e.g., the transmitted bits) or the training cost. Furthermore, the efficiency reduction in FL system is defined as:

ϵe=1K​∑k=1Kϵe,k.subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{e}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\epsilon_{e,k}.

3.5 The Competition Between The Protector and The Adversary

The Goal of the Protector The goal of protector k𝑘k is formulated as an optimization problem that aims at finding a protected distribution Pk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} achieving the minimum utility loss and efficiency reduction under the privacy constraint χksubscript𝜒𝑘\chi_{k}, which is formally expressed as

minPk𝒮⁡ηu⋅ϵu,k+ηe⋅ϵe,k,subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮⋅subscript𝜂𝑢subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑘⋅subscript𝜂𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒𝑘\displaystyle\min\limits_{P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}\eta_{u}\cdot\epsilon_{u,k}+\eta_{e}\cdot\epsilon_{e,k}, (3)
subject toϵp,k≤χk.subject tosubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑘subscript𝜒𝑘\displaystyle\text{subject to}\quad\epsilon_{p,k}\leq\chi_{k}. (4)

where ηusubscript𝜂𝑢\eta_{u} represents the preference of the protector towards model utility, and ηesubscript𝜂𝑒\eta_{e} represents the preference of the protector towards efficiency.

The Goal of the Adversary Let Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} be the client k𝑘k’s private information. Let Wk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} represent the client k𝑘k’s model information exposed to the adversary. The goal of the adversary is formally expressed as

maxFDk|Wk𝒮ϵp,k:=JS(Fk𝒜||Fkℬ),\displaystyle\max_{F_{D_{k}|W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}}\epsilon_{p,k}:={\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k}), (5)

where FDk|Wk𝒮subscript𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮F_{D_{k}|W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}} represents the adversary’s posterior distribution of the private information Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} upon observing the exposed model information Wk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}.

Competition Between the Protector and the Adversary Given the goal of the protector and the adversary formally stated in Eq. (3) and Eq. (5), the competition between the protector and the adversary is formally expressed as

minPk𝒮ηu⋅ϵu,k+ηe⋅ϵe,k,subject tomaxFDk|Wk𝒮⁡ϵp,k≤χk.subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮⋅subscript𝜂𝑢subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑘⋅subscript𝜂𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒𝑘missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsubject tosubscriptsubscript𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑘subscript𝜒𝑘missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{r@{\quad}l@{}l@{\quad}l}\quad\min\limits_{P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}&\eta_{u}\cdot\epsilon_{u,k}+\eta_{e}\cdot\epsilon_{e,k},\\ \text{subject to}&\max_{F_{D_{k}|W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}}\epsilon_{p,k}\leq\chi_{k}.\end{array} (8)

where χksubscript𝜒𝑘\chi_{k} is the privacy level required by client k𝑘k.

Remark: This optimization problem can be extended to satisfy the personalized requirement of the federated learning system. For example, if the efficiency reduction of the federated learning system is required not to exceed φksubscript𝜑𝑘\varphi_{k}, then the optimization problem is expressed as

minPk𝒮ϵu,k,subject tomaxFDk|Wk𝒮⁡ϵp,k≤χk,ϵe,k≤φk.subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒮subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑘missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsubject toformulae-sequencesubscriptsubscript𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑘subscript𝜒𝑘subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒𝑘subscript𝜑𝑘missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{r@{\quad}l@{}l@{\quad}l}\quad\min\limits_{P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}&\epsilon_{u,k},\\ \text{subject to}&\max_{F_{D_{k}|W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}}}\epsilon_{p,k}\leq\chi_{k},\epsilon_{e,k}\leq\varphi_{k}.\\ \end{array} (11)

A natural question is: is it possible to design a protection mechanism that simultaneously achieves infinitesimal privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction? In the following section, we provide a negative answer for this question in certain scenarios, which leads to our No-Free-Lunch Theorem (Theorem 4.6).

4 No Free Lunch Theorem in Federated Learning

In this section, we propose the No-Free-Lunch (NFL) theorem (Theorem 4.6), stating that it is unrealistic to expect a privacy-preserving FL algorithm to simultaneously achieve the infinitesimal privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction in certain scenarios.

Before elaborating on the NFL theorem, we introduce Assumption 4.1 and Assumption 4.2, under which the federated learning scenarios we analyze guarantee the existence of trade-offs between privacy, utility, and efficiency.

Assumption 4.1 is proposed in [50] and illustrated in Figure 3. We present it here for completeness. Intuitively, it states that the cumulative density of the near-optimal parameters is bounded, which rules out scenarios where the utility is constant and most parameters are near-optimal parameters.

Assumption 4.1.

let 𝒲fed𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝒮fed\mathcal{W}^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}} represent the support of the protected distribution Pfed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒮P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}} of the federated model information. Let 𝒲fed∗subscriptsuperscript𝒲fed\mathcal{W}^{*}_{\text{fed}} represent the set of parameters achieving the maximum utility

𝒲fed∗=argmaxw∈𝒲fedU​(w),subscriptsuperscript𝒲fedsubscriptargmax𝑤subscript𝒲fed𝑈𝑤\displaystyle\mathcal{W}^{*}_{\text{fed}}=\operatorname*{argmax}_{w\in\mathcal{W}_{\text{fed}}}U(w),

where U𝑈U represents the utility of the federated learning system. Given a non-negative constant c𝑐c, the near-optimal parameters is defined as

𝒲c={w∈𝒲fed𝒮:|U​(w∗)−U​(w)|≤c,∀w∗∈𝒲fed∗}.subscript𝒲𝑐conditional-set𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝒮fedformulae-sequence𝑈superscript𝑤𝑈𝑤𝑐for-allsuperscript𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝒲fed\mathcal{W}_{c}=\left\{w\in\mathcal{W}^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}}:\left|U(w^{*})-U(w)\right|\leq c,\forall w^{*}\in\mathcal{W}^{*}_{\text{fed}}\right\}.

Let c=Δ𝑐Δc=\Delta be the maximum constant that satisfies:

∫𝒲fed𝒮𝟙​{w∈𝒲Δ}​pWfed𝒮​(w)​𝑑w≤TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)2,\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{W}_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}}\mathbbm{1}\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{\Delta}\}p^{\mathcal{S}}_{W_{\text{fed}}}(w)dw\leq\frac{{\text{TV}}(P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}}||P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}})}{2}, (12)

where pWfed𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝒮subscript𝑊fedp^{\mathcal{S}}_{W_{\text{fed}}} represents the probability density function of the protected federated model information Wfed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊fed𝒮W_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}}. We assume that ΔΔ\Delta is positive, i.e., Δ>0Δ0\Delta>0.

Remark: The Eq. (12) states that the cumulative density of the near-optimal distorted parameters is upper-bounded by TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)2\frac{{\text{TV}}(P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}}||P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}})}{2}, which is at most 1212\frac{1}{2}. Therefore, the utility is not constant, and most distorted parameters are sub-optimal.

Remark: If the distribution of the protected model information is continuous and TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)=0{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}})=0, then there does not exist a positive constant ΔΔ\Delta satisfying Eq. (12), which implies that Assumption 4.1 does not hold. From Lemma C.3 of [50], the utility equals 00.

Let pWk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑝subscript𝑊𝑘𝒪p_{W_{k}}^{\mathcal{O}} represent the probability density of unprotected model information of client k𝑘k, and pWk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑝subscript𝑊𝑘𝒮p_{W_{k}}^{\mathcal{S}} represent the probability density of protected model information of client k𝑘k. The following Assumption 4.2 states that the distorted parameters have higher communication cost than that of the original parameters with high probability. Therefore, the expected communication cost of the distorted parameter is higher than that of the original parameter. This assumption rules out scenarios where the communication cost is constant, and the communication cost of most distorted parameters is smaller than that of the original parameters. We provide an example for illustration in Figure 4.

Assumption 4.2.

Let wmax𝒪=arg⁡maxw∈𝒲k𝒪⁡C​(w)subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝒪maxsubscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑘𝒪𝐶𝑤w^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{max}}=\arg\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}}C(w). Let ΞksubscriptΞ𝑘\Xi_{k} denote the minimum non-negative constant satisfying that C​(wmax𝒪)−Ξk≤C​(w)𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝒪maxsubscriptΞ𝑘𝐶𝑤C(w^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{max}})-\Xi_{k}\leq C(w), ∀w∈𝒲k𝒮for-all𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝒮𝑘\forall w\in\mathcal{W}^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}. Let 𝒰ksubscript𝒰𝑘\mathcal{U}_{k} represent the set of distorted parameters with improved probability density. Specifically, 𝒰k={w∈𝒲k𝒮:pWk𝒮​(w)≥pWk𝒪​(w)}subscript𝒰𝑘conditional-set𝑤superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑘𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑝subscript𝑊𝑘𝒮𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝒪subscript𝑊𝑘𝑤\mathcal{U}_{k}=\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}:p_{W_{k}}^{\mathcal{S}}(w)\geq p^{\mathcal{O}}_{W_{k}}(w)\}. We denote 𝒲k,Ξk+superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑘subscriptΞ𝑘\mathcal{W}_{k,\Xi_{k}}^{+} as the set of distorted parameters with high probability density, and the communication cost of which is larger than that of the original parameters with a gap of at least 2⋅Ξk⋅2subscriptΞ𝑘2\cdot\Xi_{k}. We denote 𝒲k,Ξk+superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑘subscriptΞ𝑘\mathcal{W}_{k,\Xi_{k}}^{+} as:

We denote 𝒲k,Ξk−=𝒰k∖𝒲k,Ξk+superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑘subscriptΞ𝑘subscript𝒰𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑘subscriptΞ𝑘\mathcal{W}_{k,\Xi_{k}}^{-}=\mathcal{U}_{k}\setminus\mathcal{W}_{k,\Xi_{k}}^{+}. Let ΓksubscriptΓ𝑘\Gamma_{k} denote the maximum constant satisfying that

∫𝒰k𝟙​{w∈𝒲k,Ξk+}​pWk𝒮​(w)​𝑑w⏟term 1−∫𝒰k𝟙​{w∈𝒲k,Ξk−}​pWk𝒮​(w)​𝑑w⏟term 2≥Γk⋅TV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮),\displaystyle\underbrace{\int_{\mathcal{U}_{k}}\mathbbm{1}\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{k,\Xi_{k}}^{+}\}p^{\mathcal{S}}_{W_{k}}(w)dw}_{\text{term $1$}}-\underbrace{\int_{\mathcal{U}_{k}}\mathbbm{1}\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{k,\Xi_{k}}^{-}\}p^{\mathcal{S}}_{W_{k}}(w)dw}_{\text{term $2$}}\geq\Gamma_{k}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}), (13)

where pWk𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝒮subscript𝑊𝑘p^{\mathcal{S}}_{W_{k}} denotes the probability density function of the protected model information and pWk𝒪subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝒪subscript𝑊𝑘p^{\mathcal{O}}_{W_{k}} denotes the probability density function of the original model information. We assume that ΞksubscriptΞ𝑘\Xi_{k} and ΓksubscriptΓ𝑘\Gamma_{k} are positive, i.e., Ξk>0,Γk>0,∀k∈[K]formulae-sequencesubscriptΞ𝑘0formulae-sequencesubscriptΓ𝑘0for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\Xi_{k}>0,\Gamma_{k}>0,\forall k\in[K].

Remark: The Eq. (13) states that the difference between the distorted parameters’ cumulative density in 𝒲k,Ξk+subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝑘subscriptΞ𝑘\mathcal{W}^{+}_{k,\Xi_{k}} and 𝒲k,Ξk−subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝑘subscriptΞ𝑘\mathcal{W}^{-}_{k,\Xi_{k}} is lower-bounded by a non-negative value. Therefore, it conveys that the expected communication cost of the distorted parameter is higher than that of the original parameter. Since Ξk>0subscriptΞ𝑘0\Xi_{k}>0, the communication cost is not constant.

In the next section, we introduce the quantitative trade-offs between privacy and efficiency and between privacy and utility, respectively. These two trade-offs lead to the main conclusion of our No-Free-Lunch theorem formulated in Theorem 4.6.

4.1 Trade-off between Privacy and Efficiency

The following Lemma 4.1 bounds efficiency reduction using the distortion measured by total variation distance TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮){\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}}). The intuition is that a larger distortion leads to a higher efficiency reduction. The analysis is deferred to Lemma B.3.

Lemma 4.1.

Let Assumption 4.2 hold, and ϵesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒\epsilon_{e} be defined in Definition 3.5. Let Pfed𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒪P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}} and Pfed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒮P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}} represent the distribution of the aggregated parameter before and after being protected. Let Ξ=mink∈[K]⁡ΞkΞsubscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾subscriptΞ𝑘\Xi=\min_{k\in[K]}\Xi_{k}, and Γ=mink∈[K]⁡ΓkΓsubscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾subscriptΓ𝑘\Gamma=\min_{k\in[K]}\Gamma_{k}. Then, we have:

ϵe≥Ξ⋅Γ⋅1K∑k=1KTV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮).\displaystyle\epsilon_{e}\geq\Xi\cdot\Gamma\cdot\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}).

The following Lemma 4.2 illustrates the quantitative relationship between ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} and total variation distance. Lemma 4.2 applies to both discrete (see proof in [50]) and continuous private information (see Lemma B.1).

Lemma 4.2.

Let ϵp,ksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑘\epsilon_{p,k} be defined in Definition 3.3, Pk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒪P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} and Pk𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝒮𝑘P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k} represent the distribution of the parameter of client k𝑘k before and after being protected. Then, we have:

ϵp≥C1−1K∑k=1KC2⋅TV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮),\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}\geq C_{1}-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}C_{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}), (14)

where C1=1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)C_{1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}, and C2=12​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶212superscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{2}=\frac{1}{2}(e^{2\xi}-1), ξksubscript𝜉𝑘\xi_{k}=maxw∈𝒲k,d∈𝒟k⁡|log⁡(fDk|Wk​(d|w)fDk​(d))|subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤subscript𝒲𝑘𝑑subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}_{k},d\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D_{k}|W_{k}}(d|w)}{f_{D_{k}}(d)}\right)\right|, and ξ𝜉\xi=maxk∈[K]⁡ξksubscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾subscript𝜉𝑘\max_{k\in[K]}\xi_{k} represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by the clients, and [K]={1,2,⋯,K}delimited-[]𝐾12⋯𝐾[K]=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}.

Intuitively, a larger distortion would increase communication costs while decreasing privacy leaks. The Lemma 4.3 demonstrates how the summation of privacy leakage and efficiency reduction is lower bounded by a constant that depends on the nature of the scenario.

Lemma 4.3 (No free lunch theorem (NFL) for privacy and efficiency).

Let ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} be defined in Def. 3.3, and let ϵesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒\epsilon_{e} be defined in Def. 3.5, with Assumption 4.2 we have:

ϵp+Cx⋅ϵe≥C1,subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝⋅subscript𝐶𝑥subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒subscript𝐶1\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}+C_{x}\cdot\epsilon_{e}\geq C_{1},

where C1=1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)C_{1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})} and Cx=12​Ξ​Γ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑥12ΞΓsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{x}=\frac{1}{2\Xi\Gamma}(e^{2\xi}-1).

4.2 Trade-off between Privacy and Utility

The Lemma 4.4 demonstrates how the total variation distance between the protected and unprotected distributions lower bounds utility loss.

Lemma 4.4.

Let Assumption 4.1 hold, and ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u} be defined in Definition 3.4. Let Pfed𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒪P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}} and Pfed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒮P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}} represent the distribution of the federated model information before and after being protected. Then, we have:

ϵu≥subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢absent\displaystyle\epsilon_{u}\geq Δ2⋅TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮).\displaystyle\frac{\Delta}{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}}).

With Lemma 4.2 and Lemma 4.4, it is now natural to provide a quantitative relationship between the utility loss and the privacy leakage.

Lemma 4.5 (No free lunch theorem (NFL) for privacy and utility).

Let ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} be defined in Def. 3.3, and let ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u} be defined in Def. 3.4 at the convergence step, with Assumption 4.1 we have:

ϵp+Cd⋅ϵu≥C1,subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝⋅subscript𝐶𝑑subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢subscript𝐶1\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}+C_{d}\cdot\epsilon_{u}\geq C_{1}, (15)

where ξksubscript𝜉𝑘\xi_{k}=maxw∈𝒲k,d∈𝒟k⁡|log⁡(fDk|Wk​(d|w)fDk​(d))|subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤subscript𝒲𝑘𝑑subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}_{k},d\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D_{k}|W_{k}}(d|w)}{f_{D_{k}}(d)}\right)\right|, and ξ𝜉\xi=maxk∈[K]⁡ξksubscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾subscript𝜉𝑘\max_{k\in[K]}\xi_{k} represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, and [K]={1,2,⋯,K}delimited-[]𝐾12⋯𝐾[K]=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}, C1=1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)C_{1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}, Cd=γ4​Δ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑑𝛾4Δsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{d}=\frac{\gamma}{4\Delta}(e^{2\xi}-1), and γ=1K∑k=1KTV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮)TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)\gamma=\frac{\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k})}{{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}})}.

Remark: If the distribution of the protected model information is continuous, and TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)=0{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}})=0, then Assumption 4.1 does not hold, and the utility loss is equal to 00 (from Lemma C.3 of [50]).

4.3 Trade-off between Privacy, Utility and Efficiency

The Theorem 4.6 illustrates the quantitative trade-off between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction, which shows that the weighted summation of these three metrics is larger than a problem-dependent constant (also exhibited in Figure 5). It implies that simultaneously achieving infinitesimal privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction is unrealistic in certain scenarios. The complete analysis is deferred to Appendix C.

Theorem 4.6 (No free lunch theorem (NFL) for privacy, utility and efficiency).

Let ϵesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒\epsilon_{e} be defined in Def. 3.5, ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} be defined in Def. 3.3, and let ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u} be defined in Def. 3.4 at the convergence step. Let Assumption 4.1 and Assumption 4.2 hold, then we have that:

ϵp+Cd2⋅ϵu+Cx2⋅ϵe≥C1,subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝⋅subscript𝐶𝑑2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢⋅subscript𝐶𝑥2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒subscript𝐶1\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}+\frac{C_{d}}{2}\cdot\epsilon_{u}+\frac{C_{x}}{2}\cdot\epsilon_{e}\geq C_{1}, (16)

where ξk=maxw∈𝒲k,d∈𝒟k⁡|log⁡(fDk|Wk​(d|w)fDk​(d))|subscript𝜉𝑘subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤subscript𝒲𝑘𝑑subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\xi_{k}=\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}_{k},d\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D_{k}|W_{k}}(d|w)}{f_{D_{k}}(d)}\right)\right|, ξ=maxk∈[K]⁡ξk𝜉subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾subscript𝜉𝑘\xi=\max_{k\in[K]}\xi_{k}, C1=1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)C_{1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}, Cd=γ4​Δ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑑𝛾4Δsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{d}=\frac{\gamma}{4\Delta}(e^{2\xi}-1), Cx=12​Ξ​Γ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑥12ΞΓsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{x}=\frac{1}{2\Xi\Gamma}(e^{2\xi}-1), γ=∑k=1KTV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮)TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)\gamma=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k})}{{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}})}.

Note that C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} measures the discrepancy between the prior belief and the posterior belief of the attacker and is typically a positive constant in real-world applications. Theorem 4.6 states that the weighted summation of the privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction is greater than or equal to C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} in certain scenarios, indicating that a protection mechanism cannot be expected to achieve exceptional privacy, utility, and efficiency simultaneously in scenarios where Assumption 4.1 and Assumption 4.2 hold.

5 Applications

In this section, we apply the No-Free-Lunch theorem to four well-adopted protection mechanisms for quantifying their trade-offs between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction.

We measure efficiency in terms of the communication cost and denote δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 as a small constant. C1=1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)C_{1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})} and C2=(e2​ξ−1)/2subscript𝐶2superscript𝑒2𝜉12C_{2}=(e^{2\xi}-1)/2 are two constants independent of the protection mechanisms adopted, and m𝑚m is the dimension of the parameter.

5.1 Randomization Mechanism

Let Wk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} be the parameter sampled from distribution Pk𝒪=𝒩​(μ0,Σ0)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒪𝒩subscript𝜇0subscriptΣ0P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}=\mathcal{N}(\mu_{0},\Sigma_{0}), where μ0∈ℝnsubscript𝜇0superscriptℝ𝑛\mu_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}, Σ0=diag​(σ12,⋯,σm2)subscriptΣ0diagsuperscriptsubscript𝜎12⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚2\Sigma_{0}=\text{diag}(\sigma_{1}^{2},\cdots,\sigma_{m}^{2}) is a diagonal matrix. The distorted parameter Wk𝒮=Wk𝒪+ϵksuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}=W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}+\epsilon_{k}, where ϵk∼𝒩​(0,Σϵ)similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘𝒩0subscriptΣitalic-ϵ\epsilon_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\Sigma_{\epsilon}) and Σϵ=diag​(σϵ2,⋯,σϵ2)subscriptΣitalic-ϵdiagsuperscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2\Sigma_{\epsilon}=\text{diag}(\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2},\cdots,\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}). The bounds for privacy leakage, utility loss and efficiency reduction for randomization mechanism is illustrated in the following theorem. The full proof is deferred to Appendix D.

Theorem 5.1.

For randomization mechanism, the privacy leakage is bounded by

ϵp≥C1−C2100⋅min⁡{1,σϵ2​∑i=1m1σi4}.subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝subscript𝐶1⋅subscript𝐶21001superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖4\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}\geq C_{1}-\frac{C_{2}}{100}\cdot\min\left\{1,\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{1}{\sigma_{i}^{4}}}\right\}.

The utility loss is bounded by

ϵu≥Δ200⋅min⁡{1,σϵ2​∑i=1m1σi4}.subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢⋅Δ2001superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖4\displaystyle\epsilon_{u}\geq\frac{\Delta}{200}\cdot\min\left\{1,\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{1}{\sigma_{i}^{4}}}\right\}.

The efficiency reduction is bounded by

ϵe≥Ξ​Γ100​min⁡{1,σϵ2​∑i=1m1σi4}.subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒ΞΓ1001superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖4\displaystyle\epsilon_{e}\geq\frac{\Xi\Gamma}{100}\min\left\{1,\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{1}{\sigma_{i}^{4}}}\right\}.

5.2 Paillier Homomorphic Encryption

The Paillier encryption mechanism proposed by [34] is an asymmetric additive homomorphic encryption mechanism, which was widely applied in FL [49, 3, 40, 8, 13]. Paillier encryption contains three parts: key generation, encryption, and decryption. Let hℎh represent the plaintext, and c𝑐c represent the ciphertext. Let (n,g𝑛𝑔n,g) represent the public key, and (λ,μ𝜆𝜇\lambda,\mu) represent the private key. Note that the primes p𝑝p and q𝑞q are rather large.

Encryption

Randomly select r𝑟r and encode hℎh as:

c=gh⋅rn​ mod ​n2,𝑐⋅superscript𝑔ℎsuperscript𝑟𝑛 mod superscript𝑛2\displaystyle c=g^{h}\cdot r^{n}\text{ mod }n^{2},

where n=p⋅q𝑛⋅𝑝𝑞n=p\cdot q, p𝑝p and q𝑞q are two selected primes. Note that g𝑔g is an integer selected randomly, and g∈ℤn2∗𝑔superscriptsubscriptℤsuperscript𝑛2g\in\mathbb{Z}_{n^{2}}^{*}. Therefore, n𝑛n can divide the order of g𝑔g.

Decryption

Using the private key (λ,μ)𝜆𝜇(\lambda,\mu) to decrypt the ciphertext c𝑐c as:

h=L​(cλ​ mod ​n2)⋅μ​ mod ​n,ℎ⋅𝐿superscript𝑐𝜆 mod superscript𝑛2𝜇 mod 𝑛\displaystyle h=L(c^{\lambda}\text{ mod }n^{2})\cdot\mu\text{ mod }n,

Let Wk𝒪=(ak1,⋯,akm)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑚W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}=(a_{k}^{1},\cdots,a_{k}^{m}) represent the plaintext parameter that follows a degenerate distribution. To facilitate the calculation of the total variation distance between the unprotected distribution of Wk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} and the protected distribution of Wk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}, we relax the discrete unprotected distribution to a continuous distribution using a parameter δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. 5.3 Secret Sharing Mechanism

Various privacy-preserving protocols based on MPC (especially secret sharing) have been proposed to build secure machine learning models, including linear regression, logistic regression, and recommendation systems. [38, 5, 6] were proposed to distribute secrets between participants.

Note that TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)=0{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}})=0 for secret sharing mechanism. From Lemma C.3 of [50], the utility loss equals 00. The communication cost for the parameter of the secret sharing mechanism is not guaranteed to satisfy Assumption 4.2, and the analysis of the lower bound of the efficiency reduction is beyond the scope of our article.

Let Wk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} represent the original model information that follows a uniform distribution over [ak1−δ,ak1+δ]×[ak2−δ,ak2+δ]​⋯×[akm−δ,akm+δ]superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘2𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘2𝛿⋯superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑚𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑚𝛿[a_{k}^{1}-\delta,a_{k}^{1}+\delta]\times[a_{k}^{2}-\delta,a_{k}^{2}+\delta]\cdots\times[a_{k}^{m}-\delta,a_{k}^{m}+\delta]. Let Wk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}} represent the distorted model information that follows uniform distribution over [ak1−bk1,ak1+rk1]×[ak2−bk2,ak2+rk2]​⋯×[akm−bkm,akm+rkm]superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘2⋯superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑚[a_{k}^{1}-b_{k}^{1},a_{k}^{1}+r_{k}^{1}]\times[a_{k}^{2}-b_{k}^{2},a_{k}^{2}+r_{k}^{2}]\cdots\times[a_{k}^{m}-b_{k}^{m},a_{k}^{m}+r_{k}^{m}]. 5.4 Compression Mechanism

For the compression mechanism, the client does not transfer all the parameters to the server. Let Wk𝒪​(i)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪𝑖W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}(i) (Wk𝒮​(i)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮𝑖W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}(i)) denote dimension i𝑖i of Wk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} (Wk𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}). Specifically, bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} takes the value 111 with probability ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}, and 00 with probability 1−ρi1subscript𝜌𝑖1-\rho_{i}. Wk𝒮​(i)={Wk𝒪​(i)if ​bi=1,0,if ​bi=0.superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒮𝑖casessuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪𝑖if subscript𝑏𝑖10if subscript𝑏𝑖0W_{k}^{\mathcal{S}}(i)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{cl}W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}(i)&\text{if }b_{i}=1,\\ 0,&\text{if }b_{i}=0.\\ \end{array}\right.

6 Conclusion and Future Work

In this work, we propose a unified federated learning (FL) framework that reconciles both HFL and VFL. Under this unified FL framework, we provide the No-Free-Lunch (NFL) theorem that quantifies the trade-off between privacy leakage, utility loss, and efficiency reduction for well-defined scenarios. We then leverage our proposed NFL theorem to analyze the lower bounds of the widely-adopted protection mechanisms, including the randomization mechanism, Paillier mechanism, secret sharing mechanism, and compression mechanism.

Lots of problems are worth investigating. In this work, we use the Jensen-Shannon (JS) divergence instead of the commonly-used KL divergence to measure privacy leakage. The JS divergence is expressed as the summation of two KL divergences. Thus, it inherits the advantages of KL divergence. Besides, JS divergence satisfies the triangle inequality, which facilitates the theoretical analysis. One potential question is, if we use a generalized version of JS-divergence weighted using a hyperparameter α𝛼\alpha [9], are we still able to bound the privacy leakage and quantify the trade-off analysis?

The optimal privacy-utility-efficiency trade-off is cast as a constrained optimization problem in which the utility loss and efficiency reduction are minimized subject to a predefined constraint for privacy leakage. The optimization problem and the derived lower bounds provide an avenue for proposing meta-algorithms that search the optimal hyperparameter characterizing the protection mechanism. Designing a meta-algorithm that seeks to determine the ideal protection hyperparameter at each communication round is an intriguing problem. Whether it is possible to design an algorithm that can learn the hyperparameter adaptively is another promising research direction.

Appendix B Lower Bounds for Privacy Leakage, Utility Loss and Efficiency Reduction

When the private information D𝐷D is discrete, the privacy leakage could be lower bounded by the total variation distance between Pk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒪P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} and Pk𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝒮𝑘P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}, as is shown in the following lemma.

Lemma B.1.

Let ϵp,ksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑘\epsilon_{p,k} be defined in Definition 3.3. Let Pk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝒪P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} and Pk𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝒮𝑘P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k} represent the distribution of the parameter of client k𝑘k before and after being protected. Then for any client k𝑘k, we have that

ϵp,k≥JS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)−12(e2​ξ−1)TV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮).\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,k}\geq\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}-\frac{1}{2}(e^{2\xi}-1){\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}). (17)

Furthermore, we have that

ϵp≥1K∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)−1K∑k=1K12(e2​ξ−1)⋅TV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮).\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}\geq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{2}(e^{2\xi}-1)\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}).

≤14(e2​ξ−1)2TV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮)2.\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{4}(e^{2\xi}-1)^{2}{\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k})^{2}.

∎

With the above lemma, now we are ready to show Lemma B.1 when the private information D𝐷D is discrete, the analysis is similar to the continuous scenario.

Proof.

The square root of JS divergence satisfies triangle inequality, which implies that

JS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)−JS(Fk𝒜||Fkℬ)≤JS(Fk𝒜||Fk𝒪),\displaystyle\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}-\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}\leq\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k})},

where JS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})} is a problem-dependent constant, JS(Fk𝒜||Fkℬ)\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})} represents the privacy leakage, and JS(Fk𝒜||Fk𝒪)≤12(e2​ξ−1)TV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮)\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k})}\leq\frac{1}{2}(e^{2\xi}-1){\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}) from Lemma B.2. Therefore, ∀k∈[K]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\forall k\in[K], we have that

JS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)\displaystyle\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})} ≤ϵp,k+12(e2​ξ−1)TV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮).\displaystyle\leq\epsilon_{p,k}+\frac{1}{2}(e^{2\xi}-1){\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}).

∎

Lemma B.3.

Appendix C Trade-off Between Privacy, Utility and Efficiency

First, we quantify the trade-off between privacy and efficiency. The following lemma illustrates that the summation of the privacy leakage and the efficiency reduction is lower bounded by a problem-dependent constant.

Lemma C.1 (No free lunch theorem (NFL) for privacy and efficiency).

Let ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} be defined in Def. 3.3, and let ϵesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒\epsilon_{e} be defined in Def. 3.5, with Assumption 4.2 we have:

ϵp+Cx⋅ϵe≥C1,subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝⋅subscript𝐶𝑥subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒subscript𝐶1\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}+C_{x}\cdot\epsilon_{e}\geq C_{1},

where C1=1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)C_{1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})} and Cx=12​Ξ​Γ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑥12ΞΓsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{x}=\frac{1}{2\Xi\Gamma}(e^{2\xi}-1).

Proof.

First, from Lemma 4.2 we have that

ϵp≥1K∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)−1K∑k=1K12(e2​ξ−1)⋅TV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮),\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}\geq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{2}(e^{2\xi}-1)\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}),

From Lemma 4.1, we have

ϵe≥Ξ⋅Γ⋅1K∑k=1KTV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮).\displaystyle\epsilon_{e}\geq\Xi\cdot\Gamma\cdot\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k}).

Combining the above two equations, we have that

1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)≤ϵp+12​Ξ​Γ​(e2​ξ−1)​ϵe,\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}\leq\epsilon_{p}+\frac{1}{2\Xi\Gamma}(e^{2\xi}-1)\epsilon_{e},

where ϵp=1K​∑k=1Kϵp,ksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑘\epsilon_{p}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\epsilon_{p,k}.
The above equation could be further simplified as

C1subscript𝐶1\displaystyle C_{1} ≤ϵp+Cx​ϵe,absentsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝subscript𝐶𝑥subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒\displaystyle\leq\epsilon_{p}+C_{x}\epsilon_{e},

where C1=1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)C_{1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})} and Cx=12​Ξ​Γ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑥12ΞΓsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{x}=\frac{1}{2\Xi\Gamma}(e^{2\xi}-1). ∎

The trade-off between privacy and utility was the main result shown in [50], the analysis of which is applicable to a more general definition for utility loss (Definition 3.4). The following lemma illustrates that utility loss is lower bounded by the total variation distance between the unprotected and protected distributions.

Lemma C.2.

[50] Let Assumption 4.1 hold, and ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u} be defined in Definition 3.4. Let Pfed𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒪P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{O}} and Pfed𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑃fed𝒮P_{\text{fed}}^{\mathcal{S}} represent the distribution of the aggregated parameter before and after being protected. Then we have,

ϵu≥Δ2⋅TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮).\displaystyle\epsilon_{u}\geq\frac{\Delta}{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}}).

With Lemma B.1 and Lemma C.2, it is now natural to provide a quantitative relationship between the utility loss and the privacy leakage (Theorem C.3).

Theorem C.3.

[50][No free lunch theorem (NFL) for privacy and utility] Let ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} be defined in Def. 3.3, and let ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u} be defined in Def. 3.4 at the convergence step, with Assumption 4.1 we have:

ϵp+Cd⋅ϵu≥C1,subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝⋅subscript𝐶𝑑subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢subscript𝐶1\displaystyle\epsilon_{p}+C_{d}\cdot\epsilon_{u}\geq C_{1}, (27)

where ξksubscript𝜉𝑘\xi_{k}=maxw∈𝒲k,d∈𝒟k⁡|log⁡(fDk|Wk​(d|w)fDk​(d))|subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤subscript𝒲𝑘𝑑subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}_{k},d\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D_{k}|W_{k}}(d|w)}{f_{D_{k}}(d)}\right)\right|, and ξ𝜉\xi=maxk∈[K]⁡ξksubscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾subscript𝜉𝑘\max_{k\in[K]}\xi_{k} represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, and [K]={1,2,⋯,K}delimited-[]𝐾12⋯𝐾[K]=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}, C1=1K​∑k=1KJS(Fk𝒪||Fkℬ)C_{1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k}||F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k})}, Cd=γ4​Δ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑑𝛾4Δsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{d}=\frac{\gamma}{4\Delta}(e^{2\xi}-1), and γ=1K∑k=1KTV(Pk𝒪||Pk𝒮)TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)\gamma=\frac{\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\text{TV}}(P_{k}^{\mathcal{O}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k})}{{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}})}.

With Theorem C.1 and Theorem C.3, our main result Theorem 4.6 is proven.

Appendix E Analysis for Paillier Homomorphic Encryption

The Paillier encryption mechanism was proposed by [34] is an asymmetric additive homomorphic encryption mechanism, which was widely applied in FL [49, 3, 40, 8]. We first introduce the basic definition of Paillier algorithm in federated learning [13]. Paillier encyption contains three parts including key generation, encryption and decryption. Let hℎh represent the plaintext, and c𝑐c represent the ciphertext.

Key Generation

Let (n,g𝑛𝑔n,g) represent the public key, and (λ,μ𝜆𝜇\lambda,\mu) represent the private key. Select two primes p𝑝p and q𝑞q that are rather large, satisfying that gcd​(p​q,(p−q)​(q−1))=1gcd𝑝𝑞𝑝𝑞𝑞11\text{gcd}(pq,(p-q)(q-1))=1. Select g𝑔g randomly satisfying that g∈ℤn2∗𝑔superscriptsubscriptℤsuperscript𝑛2g\in\mathbb{Z}_{n^{2}}^{*}. Let n=p⋅q𝑛⋅𝑝𝑞n=p\cdot q, λ=lcm​(p−1,q−1)𝜆lcm𝑝1𝑞1\lambda=\text{lcm}(p-1,q-1), and μ=(L​(gλ​ mod ​n2))−1​ mod ​n𝜇superscript𝐿superscript𝑔𝜆 mod superscript𝑛21 mod 𝑛\mu=(L(g^{\lambda}\text{ mod }n^{2}))^{-1}\text{ mod }n.

Encryption

Randomly select r𝑟r and encode hℎh as:

c=gh⋅rn​ mod ​n2,𝑐⋅superscript𝑔ℎsuperscript𝑟𝑛 mod superscript𝑛2\displaystyle c=g^{h}\cdot r^{n}\text{ mod }n^{2},

where n=p⋅q𝑛⋅𝑝𝑞n=p\cdot q, p𝑝p and q𝑞q are two selected primes. Note that g𝑔g is an integer selected randomly, and g∈ℤn2∗𝑔superscriptsubscriptℤsuperscript𝑛2g\in\mathbb{Z}_{n^{2}}^{*}. Therefore, n𝑛n can divide the order of g𝑔g.

Decryption

Using the private key (λ,μ)𝜆𝜇(\lambda,\mu) to decrypt the ciphertext c𝑐c as:

h=L​(cλ​ mod ​n2)⋅μ​ mod ​n,ℎ⋅𝐿superscript𝑐𝜆 mod superscript𝑛2𝜇 mod 𝑛\displaystyle h=L(c^{\lambda}\text{ mod }n^{2})\cdot\mu\text{ mod }n,

where L​(x)=x−1n𝐿𝑥𝑥1𝑛L(x)=\frac{x-1}{n}, μ=(L​(gλ​ mod ​n2))−1​ mod ​n𝜇superscript𝐿superscript𝑔𝜆 mod superscript𝑛21 mod 𝑛\mu=(L(g^{\lambda}\text{ mod }n^{2}))^{-1}\text{ mod }n, and λ=lcm​(p−1,q−1)𝜆lcm𝑝1𝑞1\lambda=\text{lcm}(p-1,q-1).

Let m𝑚m represent the dimension of the parameter.

  • •

    Let Wk𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝒪W_{k}^{\mathcal{O}} represent the plaintext that follows a uniform distribution over [ak1−δ,ak1+δ]×[ak2−δ,ak2+δ]×⋯×[akm−δ,akm+δ]superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘2𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘2𝛿⋯superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑚𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑚𝛿[a_{k}^{1}-\delta,a_{k}^{1}+\delta]\times[a_{k}^{2}-\delta,a_{k}^{2}+\delta]\times\cdots\times[a_{k}^{m}-\delta,a_{k}^{m}+\delta].

For Paillier mechanism, the distorted parameter given secret key becomes the original parameter. The following lemma shows that the utility loss for Paillier mechanism is 00.

Lemma E.2.

For Paillier mechanism, the utility loss ϵu=0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢0\epsilon_{u}=0.

Proof.

Let Pfed𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝒮fedP^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}} represent the distribution of the distorted parameter which is decrypted by the client. Note that TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮)=0{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}})=0. From Lemma C.3 of [50], the utility loss is equal to 00. ∎

Appendix F Analysis for Secret Sharing Mechanism

Many MPC-based protocols (particularly secret sharing) are used to build secure machine learning models, such as linear regression, logistic regression, recommend systems, and so on. [38, 5, 6] were developed to distribute a secret among a group of participants.

Let m𝑚m represent the dimension of the model information.

  • •

ϵu≥Δ2⋅TV(Pfed𝒪||Pfed𝒮).\displaystyle\epsilon_{u}\geq\frac{\Delta}{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{\mathcal{O}}_{\text{fed}}||P^{\mathcal{S}}_{\text{fed}}). (35)

ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\displaystyle\epsilon_{u} ≥Δ2⋅((12​δ)m−∏i=1m(ρi2​δ))⋅(2​δ)mabsent⋅Δ2superscript12𝛿𝑚superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜌𝑖2𝛿superscript2𝛿𝑚\displaystyle\geq\frac{\Delta}{2}\cdot\left(\left(\frac{1}{2\delta}\right)^{m}-\prod_{i=1}^{m}\left(\frac{\rho_{i}}{2\delta}\right)\right)\cdot(2\delta)^{m}
=Δ2⋅(1−∏i=1mρi).absent⋅Δ21superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜌𝑖\displaystyle=\frac{\Delta}{2}\cdot\left(1-\prod_{i=1}^{m}\rho_{i}\right).

∎
